### **1. Your Copyright Exists Automatically (No Registration Needed)**
- **UK law (Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988)** protects your work **the moment itâ€™s created and fixed in a tangible form** (e.g., uploaded online). You donâ€™t need to register it or add a Â© symbol for protection.
- **Your rights as the author**:
  - **Economic rights**: You control reproduction, distribution, adaptation, and public communication of your work.
  - **Moral rights**:
    - **Right to be identified as the author** (paternity right) â€“ though this can be waived (you likely didnâ€™t waive it).
    - **Right to object to derogatory treatment** (if your work is distorted in a way that harms your reputation).
    - **Right to object to false attribution** (if someone else is credited for your work).

**Key point**: The AI company **scraping your work without permission** to train their model is likely a **copyright infringement** (more on this below). The userâ€™s ad using your character is also infringement.

### **2. Is AI Training an Infringement? (The Big Legal Question)**
This is a **hotly debated** issue, but UK law is increasingly leaning toward **yes, it is infringement** if done without permission. Hereâ€™s why:

#### **A. Text and Data Mining (TDM) Exception (UK Law)**
- The UK has a **limited exception** for TDM (s.29A CDPA 1988), but it **only applies to non-commercial research or private study**.
- **Synthetic Dreams Corp is a commercial entity**, so this exception **does not apply** to them.
- Even if they claim "research," training a commercial AI model for profit is **not covered** by the exception.

#### **B. EU/UK Case Law (Recent Developments)**
- The **EUâ€™s AI Act** (which the UK may follow) requires **transparency and consent** for copyrighted works used in AI training.
- In **2023, the UK High Court ruled** (in *Getty Images v. Stability AI*) that AI training on copyrighted works **without permission can be infringement**.
- The **US is also cracking down**: The New York Times is suing OpenAI/Microsoft for similar issues.

**Bottom line**: Synthetic Dreams Corp **likely infringed your copyright** by scraping and training on your work without permission.

---

### **3. The Fizzy Drink Ad: Direct Infringement**
The ad using your character **Ophelia** is a **clear case of copyright infringement** because:
- The user **reproduced and adapted** your work (even if slightly altered).
- The ad was **commercial use** (not fair dealing for criticism, review, or parody).
- **No credit was given** (violating your moral rights, if you didnâ€™t waive them).

**Key point**: The user **and** Synthetic Dreams Corp (as the enabler) could both be liable.

---

### **4. What Can You Do? (Practical Steps)**
#### **A. Gather Evidence**
- **Screenshots** of your original work (with timestamps if possible).
- **Proof of upload dates** (e.g., Wayback Machine archives, social media posts).
- **The AI-generated ad** (save the video/image and any credits).
- **Any communications** with the AI company or the user (if applicable).

#### **B. Send a Cease & Desist Letter**
- **To Synthetic Dreams Corp**:
  - Demand they **stop using your work** in their training data.
  - Ask for **compensation** (licensing fees they should have paid).
  - Request **credit** for your work in their modelâ€™s documentation.
- **To the fizzy drink company/ad agency**:
  - Demand they **remove the ad** or **credit you properly**.
  - Ask for **compensation** for unauthorized use.

**Template for a C&D letter** (adjust as needed):
> *"I am the creator of the graphic novel 'Nexus,' including the character Ophelia, which you have used without permission in [describe use]. This constitutes copyright infringement under the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988. I demand that you [cease use/remove the ad/credit me/compensate me] within [X] days. Failure to comply may result in legal action."*

#### **C. Consider Legal Action**
- **Small Claims Track (UK Intellectual Property Enterprise Court - IPEC)**:
  - For claims up to **Â£10,000**, you can sue **without a lawyer** (costs are capped).
  - You can claim **damages** (lost licensing fees) and **injunctions** (to stop further use).
- **Full Court Action (for larger claims)**:
  - If the ad was high-profile, you might seek **higher damages**.
  - A solicitor specializing in **IP/copyright law** can help (e.g., [IPSE](https://www.ipse.co.uk/) or [LawBite](https://www.lawbite.co.uk/)).

#### **D. Public Pressure & Media**
- **Name and shame** on social media (tag the companies involved).
- **Contact journalists** (e.g., *The Guardian*, *BBC*, *Creative Review*)â€”AI art theft is a hot topic.
- **Petition platforms** like Change.org can amplify your case.

#### **E. Report to Platforms**
- If the ad is on **YouTube, Instagram, etc.**, file a **DMCA takedown** (even though itâ€™s a UK issue, many platforms comply).
- Report Synthetic Dreams Corp to **their hosting provider** (e.g., AWS, Google Cloud) for copyright violations.

---

### **5. What Are Your Chances of Winning?**
- **Very good**, especially if:
  - You can prove **your work was created first** (timestamps, upload dates).
  - The AI company **didnâ€™t have permission** to use your work.
  - The ad **directly copied** your character (not just "inspired by").
- **Challenges**:
  - AI companies may argue **"fair dealing"** (but this is weak for commercial use).
  - They might claim **"transformative use"** (but UK law is stricter than US on this).
  - **Jurisdiction**: If Synthetic Dreams Corp is US-based, you may need to sue in the US (expensive, but possible with a lawyer).

---

### **6. How to Protect Yourself in the Future**
- **Watermark your work** (subtly, so itâ€™s hard to remove).
- **Use reverse image search** (e.g., Google Lens, TinEye) to monitor unauthorized use.
- **Register with the UK Copyright Service** (not required, but adds extra proof).
- **Add a copyright notice** (e.g., "Â© [Your Name] 2024. All rights reserved.").
- **Consider Creative Commons licenses** (if you want to allow some uses but not commercial AI training).
- **Join artist advocacy groups** (e.g., [Artistsâ€™ Union England](https://www.artistsunionengland.org.uk/), [Concept Art Association](https://conceptartassociation.org/)).

---

### **7. Emotional & Financial Support**
- This is **not your fault**. Many artists are being exploited by AI companiesâ€”youâ€™re not alone.
- **Crowdfunding** (e.g., Ko-fi, Patreon) can help cover legal costs.
- **Therapy or artist support groups** can help with the stress (e.g., [Mind](https://www.mind.org.uk/)).

### **Final Verdict: You Have a Strong Case**
- **Synthetic Dreams Corp infringed your copyright** by training on your work without permission.
- **The fizzy drink ad infringed your copyright** by reproducing your character without credit.
- **You can take legal action** (even without registration) and **likely win**.
- **Public pressure can force a settlement** (many companies back down when called out).
